author: Lee Carter
title: N.Hoolywood Fall 2017 Menswear Collection - Vogue
text: by Lee Carter Despite Daisuke Obana’s insistence that his Fall collection for N.Hoolywood was not politically motivated, you couldn’t help but look at the trash heaps of human suffering shuffling down the runway in the homeless-themed show and immediately connect them with the buzzwords of the last week: refugees, travel ban, American carnage . Nonetheless, lest anyone feel triggered, this was not intended to be exploitative or especially topical. Indeed, if you could put aside the rabid p.c. voice in your head, it was possible to appreciate these clothes purely on their artistic merit. On that level, it was a pretty fantastic show, Obana’s most compelling yet. Compelling in that all the categories at his, ahem, disposal—knits, coats, denim, sweats—were shown together, piled high on each dejected model. Obana said he based the concept on his observations, while traveling to cities around the U.S., of those who lived on the street and how it seemed they wore much of what they owned all at once. He thought it was clever, this ability to adapt. Besides, he added, the homeless he observed were mostly gutter punks, a subculture with a unique style—similar to everyday punks, only more down and out—who choose, apparently, to live on the street.
